title: Part (a)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not accurately include either of the criteria below.
The response accurately includes the first criterion below, but not the second.
The response accurately includes both of the criteria below.

title: Part (b)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response must both state that the equilibrium real interest rate will be higher and explain why in order to receive the point.
descriptions: The response does not state that the equilibrium real interest will be higher and/or does not explain that this is because increased government spending financed by borrowing increases the demand for loanable funds (or decreases the supply of loanable funds).

The response states that the equilibrium real interest rate will be higher and explains that this is because increased government spending financed by borrowing will increase the demand for loanable funds (or decreases the supply of loanable funds).

title: Part (c)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the amount of private savings would increase.
The response states that the amount of private savings would increase.

title: Part (d)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response must state that both the nominal interest rate will be equal to the real interest rate and explain why.
descriptions: The response does not state that the nominal interest rate will be equal to the real interest rate and/or does not explain that the real interest rate is the nominal interest rate adjusted for inflation; therefore, when the expected inflation rate is zero, the nominal interest rate is equal to the real interest rate.

The response states that the nominal interest rate will be equal to the real interest rate and explains that the real interest rate is the nominal interest rate adjusted for inflation; therefore, when the expected inflation rate is zero, the nominal interest rate is equal to the real interest rate.
